Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @heguli97 just FYI, modern CPUs are better to mine VerusHash/BTCH than GPUs. Using GPUs you already own is fine, but buying new GPUs to mine VerusHash just doesn't make much sense, unless you have zero power costs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> Fgpa cheaters very similar to the new ASIC miners arising on the algorithm from nowhere. I was also surprised how people with such complexity do not leave Verus mining.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Takoy_Nahal what makes FPGAs "cheaters"? It's a more efficient device to mine

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> @dukeleto Yes, more effective, but concentrated in much narrower circles. As I know, mining for truly decentralized projects is intended for a wide range of people, because many do not have the money for large farms or the purchase of FPGAs. For them, there is a POS where each holder of a small amount of coins can be rewarded,
the same situation with the GPU, which provides for the creation of a community of a wide range of people, even for those who can afford to buy no more than one farm. If the project wants ASIC or FPGA there are no problems, their right and opinion is that they are more efficient means of mining,
but let them not be surprised by the circle of large holders and the sharp drops in the price of a coin, because the ASIC miner's task is to discourage the investment until his ASIC as L +, D3 has turned into a useless piece of iron. But if they are counting on attracting a wide mass of people, they should be POS and not Masternodes, there should be a GPU and not FPGA or ASIC.
It's my opinion

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> VTC is "ASIC resistant" but due to this became less secure and 51% attacked

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> having hundreds of thousands double spent, about 1% of marketcap

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> ultimately coin security needs to be the first priority, with all else done as long as it doesnt hurt the coin security

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> 51% resistance has to take into account nicehash and the immense hashrate that can be centralized around a single renter

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> pretending any algo can remain GPU only for any length of time is naive

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> and believing if it is GPU only it cant be 51% attacked, even more so

Author: Gateway#3763

Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> And the VTC is no longer ASIC Resistance, the Chinese created the ASIC for Lyra2rev more than 1-2 months ago, the VTC will have a hard fork to change the algorithm. It is the emergence of ASIC contributed to the hacking VTC

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> By the way, Wikipedia reminds us that Equihash was created as an ASIC resistance algorithm.

It was the moment when Bitcoin gold was on Equihash algorithm and ASICs worked, they changed the algorithm to Zhash, until I heard about the new attack

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> How I started this topic. I just wanted to say that there are less efficient mining tools than ASIC or FPGA, but much more attracted to the general mass of new people.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> Imagine you chose a coin, you like its idea, it promotes what is extracted on the ASIC resistance algorithm, and after a while ASIC appears and the developers tell you I'm sorry brother, the time has changed there are more efficient mining tools, we will not change the algorithm and discard the original ideas.
Or maybe I'm wrong and Equihash was not conceived for this?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> Then a reasonable question will arise. Why did you guys not initially choose the Scrypt or SHA-256 algorithm and fool people?)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Takoy_Nahal fighting these FPGAs is very different than ASICs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> coin developers can brick an ASIC, make it basically worthless. You can't do that to an FPGA

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> you can "make the fpga not work on that coin until somebody changes the code"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and if a coin forks to protect itself, the next version of code, it will be sold privately, not given out publicly

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> that is the situation VRSC is in now, and it's very relevant to what BTCH will do

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> any coin that uses current verushash algo will be an FPGA coin

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> Is Verus going to defend against FPGA or won't it change anything?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Verus doesn't have a lot of good options

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> if it were an ASIC, they could brick it via code change (which would be controversial but still a protection)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> with FPGAs, a new bit of code can be written, to deal with "VerusHash V2". It's a "cat and mouse" game, both sides have about even abilities. Neither side can stop the other from playing

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> FPGAs are not new, I heard about them in 2011 when I first started BTC mining. The best BTC miners were using custom FPGAs in 2010/2011
